title: How to Make Huaraches

steps.headline: Mix together masa flour, baking powder, salt, and broth in a bowl.
steps.description: Pour 2 cups (473 g) of masa flour into a medium-sized bowl. Mix in 1 tsp (5 g) of baking powder, 1/4 tsp (3.7 g) of salt, and 1.75 cups (410 mL) of broth. You can use chicken, beef, or vegetable broth, based on your dietary preferences.

steps.headline: Stir the ingredients together until the dough holds together well.
steps.description: Use a mixing spoon to blend your ingredients together. If you need to, use a few drops of water to help your dough stay together. Your dough is ready to use when the ingredients are completely mixed and it easily stays in one blob.

steps.headline: Separate and shape the dough into four 6 in (15 cm) sections.
steps.description: Rip the dough with your hands, or cut the dough with a knife to create 4 equal sections. Then, use a rolling pin or your hands to flatten the dough. As you flatten it, aim to stretch out the dough so it is about 6 in (15 cm) long. This creates 4 huaraches.

steps.headline: Shape each section into an ⁄8 in (0.32 cm) thick oval.
steps.description: Once you flatten out the huarache and get its basic shape, you can continue shaping it so the oval is about ⁄8 in (0.32 cm) thick and the total length is about 8 in (20 cm). Use your hands to shape the dough until they are all about the same size. While this doesn't have to be perfect, it is the general size of traditional huaraches.

steps.headline: Stack each section with wax paper if you want to to store them.
steps.description: If you aren't making the huaraches right away, place a piece of wax paper about 5 in × 10 in (13 cm × 25 cm) big on top of a huarache, and put another one on top. Then, place another piece of wax paper over the second huarache. Continue doing this for all of your huaraches. Refrigerate your dough for a maximum of 2 hours. You can prep the dough in the morning and make huaraches for lunch, for instance.

steps.headline: Put oil in a large frying pan and heat it for 1 minute.
steps.description: Pour about 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of vegetable or olive oil into the pan, and use a medium heat setting. This way, you do not burn your huaraches. After about 1 minute, you're ready to cook your huaraches. The oil will start to bubble.

steps.headline: Cook the masa dough for 1 minute or so.
steps.description: Flip 1 of the huaraches onto the pan, and let it warm up for 1 minute or so. You want the bottom to develop a skin and start to firm up. Once the bottom is slightly brown, you can flip it over to cook the other side.

steps.headline: Flip the huarache to the other side and cook it for 1 minute.
steps.description: Scoop up the huarache and turn it upside down so the uncooked side faces the pan. Use a spatula to flip over the huarache.

steps.headline: Continue flipping the huarache until both sides are light brown.
steps.description: Flip the huarache 4-5 times to cook it evenly on both sides, and wait about 1 minute in between each flip. When both sides are light brown, it is done and ready to serve. If you notice a couple burn marks, that's okay!

steps.headline: Put the huarache on a plate when you finish cooking it.
steps.description: Once both sides are nice and brown, use your spatula to remove it from the pan and deliver the huarache to your plate. This way, you can easily add your toppings and dig in. Repeat the process for each huarache. Add another 1 tbsp (14.8 g) of oil to your pan as needed. To keep the huarache warm as you cook the other ones, cover it with an additional plate.

steps.headline: Cover the huarache with a thin layer of beans.
steps.description: Choose to use either black, pinto, or refried beans. Heat up your beans in the microwave or stovetop, and cover the middle of your huaraches. You can scoop your beans from a bowl with a spoon and dump them onto the huaraches. Then, spread the beans out with the back of the spoon. To heat them up on the stove, pour your beans into a medium saucepan and cook them on medium heat for 3-5 minutes. To microwave your beans, read your can for specific instruction. Typically, you can heat them up in a microwave-safe bowl for about 1-2 minutes on medium heat. Do not heat up the beans while inside of the can.

steps.headline: Add cooked meat, tofu, or veggies to your huarache.
steps.description: Put cooked ground beef, chicken, steak, tofu, or veggies on top of the layer of beans. You can prepare 1-2 lbs (453.6 - 907.2 g) of protein or veggies in advance, then evenly distribute it across all 4 huaraches. Fill your huaraches with as much as you'd like. Use tofu, sauteed veggies, or no meat if you are a vegetarian or vegan. If sauteeing veggies, use things like peppers, onions, and mushrooms. You can season your protein choice with ingredients like cumin, paprika, chili powder, lime juice, and salt.

steps.headline: Top your huarache with chopped lettuce or shredded cabbage.
steps.description: You can easily purchased shredded lettuce or cabbage. If you are chopping your produce yourself, use a large, sharp knife and cut the lettuce or cabbage into small bites. Sprinkle the lettuce or cabbage on top of the meat, tofu, or veggies. To chop either lettuce or cabbage, cut off the base and throw it away. Then, start making slices down the crop every ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) or so until you reach the end. You can then cut the pieces even smaller if you'd like. If you'd like, you can throw some cilantro on top of the lettuce or cabbage as well.

steps.headline: Add chopped onion and tomato for authentic flavor additions.
steps.description: If tomatoes and onions suit your fancy, chop them up with a large, sharp knife, and use them to top your huaraches as well. While this is optional, both are traditional ingredients used when preparing huaraches in Mexico. To chop the tomato, cut off the vine and slice the fruit horizontally every ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) or so. To chop the onion, peel off the flaky outer layers, and chop the onion horizontally every ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) or so. If you'd like, you can cut the tomato and onion into smaller pieces.

steps.headline: Sprinkle an even layer of shredded cheese on top of the lettuce.
steps.description: You can use any cheese you'd like. For an authentic option, go with queso fresco or queso blanco. Take the cheese crumbles and lightly cover the top of your huarache with an even layer. Queso fresco is inexpensive, delicious, and crumbly, making it the perfect cheese for huaraches. You can also use cheddar or goat cheese.

steps.headline: Add a dollop of salsa and/or sour cream.
steps.description: If you want to add some extra flavor to your huaraches, scoop up a dollop of sour cream with a spoon, and dump it over top the huaraches. Choose between red or green tomatillo salsa, and pour an even, light layer over top of your huaraches. Both add authentic, delicious flavor to your meal.

steps.headline: Take a bite when you are ready to dig in!
steps.description: To eat your huarache, hold it in both hands and take a bite from one of the ends. Huaraches are a popular street food, making it easy to eat these on the go. You don't need a fork, and you can eat the huarache without folding it up, as well.
